brief_summary.textblock:
Clinical study in Interventional Radiology patients which procedure was done using the
      femoral artery, in order to demonstrate the Efficacy superiority of Angio-Seal™ vs. Manual
      Compression, without increasing the risk for the patients.

clinical_study.brief_title: AGIR Study: Angio-Seal in Interventional Radiology

detailed_description.textblock:
Patients will have their puncture closure randomly performed by one of these approved
      methods: Angio-Seal™ Closure device or Manual Compression.

      Patients will be enrolled in the study during 12 months, with a follow-up period of 2 weeks
      (± 1 week).

      The randomization will be stratified according to the type of procedure.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patient ≥ 18 years Interventional Radiology procedures with Femoral Artery puncture
             (4Frenchs - 8Frenchs Introducers)

          -  Patient available for follow-up at 2 weeks

          -  Patients who are willing to participate and have signed an Ethic Committee approved
             patient informed consent.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Access unsuitable for use of Angio-Sea

          -  Presence of calcification at the puncture site

          -  Presence of visible hematoma at the end of the procedure

          -  Patients who are unable to comply with the follow-up schedule based on their
             geographic location or for any reason.

          -  Patients who are pregnant.

          -  Patients currently participating in a clinical investigation that includes an active
             treatment arm.

          -  Contraindication for ambulation at 2 hours after the end of the procedure

          -  Patients with a life expectancy of less then 1 month.

clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy Superiority of Angio-Seal™ vs. Manual Compression in Interventional Radiology

overall_official.affiliation: Hospital Universitario de La Princesa, Madrid

oversight_info.authority: Spain: Agencia Española de Medicamentos y Productos Sanitarios

primary_outcome.description: The time that patient gets the authorization to flex the leg, sit or walk.
Complications since the puncture closure until 2 weeks ± 1 week.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Time from the beginning of closure procedure, until the physician take away their hands from the patient, regardless the closure procedure, and confirm the "stop of bleeding".
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Time interval timed from the begining of the procedure to the end of bleeding.

secondary_outcome.description: The outcome measure will be assessed if the instant of stop bleeding is no longer than 5 seconds.

According the physician criteria, it will be "YES" If the anchor was deliver properly, the absorbable component remain in the correct point of the arterial puncture and no bleeding in the skin puncture.

Time that the physician grants the patient the discharge order from the Radiology Department. If the patients has order to be hospitalized up to 24h after the puncture closure by the radiologist, then, the discharge from the radiology department will be 24h, even if the patient needs to continue hospitalized in other department.
secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Discharge from Interventional Radiology Department

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment
